page.title: 07Problems of open air theatre
page.content: Being an open air theatre, the weather probably poses the greatest problem. Therefore an alternative night system was introduced in 1967. Transport is as much of a problem- if the winds and tides are wrong, the boats cannot travel, so the performances cannot take place. If the tides become dangerous during a performance, the play may end early. Mosquitoes are also a problem- the whole acting area is sprayed with repelent half an hour before every performance. Make-up also has to be applied twice as the performance starts in daylight and continues under artificial light, as night falls. The actual lighting too can pose problems, as being on an island, the electricity supply is limited. Voice projection is sometimes hampered by wind direction.
